message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the empty bottle of clomipramine suggest tricyclic antidepressant overdose. This can lead to cardiac toxicity, which is characterized by widening of the QRS complexes on ECG. Sodium bicarbonate can be used to treat this toxicity. Induced vomiting is not recommended as the patient is already unresponsive. Norepinephrine can worsen the cardiac toxicity. Diazepam is not indicated for this toxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing signs of tricyclic antidepressant overdose, which can lead to cardiotoxicity and seizures. Sodium bicarbonate is the treatment of choice to correct the cardiotoxicity by stabilizing the myocardial cell membrane and improving intracellular sodium and calcium exchange. Induced vomiting is not recommended as it may worsen the patient's condition, and norepinephrine and diazepam will not treat the cardiac toxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose, including widened QRS complexes on ECG, dry oral mucosa, and decreased respiratory rate. Sodium bicarbonate can be used in TCA overdose to correct the acidosis and improve cardiac conduction. Induced vomiting is not recommended as the patient is already unresponsive. Norepinephrine can worsen the hypertension. Diazepam is not indicated as the patient is already unresponsive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest an overdose of clomipramine, which can cause anticholinergic toxicity and wide QRS complex on ECG. Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat the widening QRS complex. Induced vomiting is not recommended due to the risk of aspiration. Norepinephrine can worsen the patient's condition. Diazepam is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Clomipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant that can cause QRS prolongation and arrhythmias. The widening of QRS complexes in the ECG suggests a sodium channel blockade. Sodium bicarbonate can help increase the pH of the blood and tissue, and, thus, reverse the blockade. Induced vomiting is not recommended when the patient is unconscious, and norepinephrine can worsen the arrhythmias. Diazepam may decrease respiratory rate, which is already low.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest clomipramine toxicity, which can cause QRS widening on ECG and respiratory distress. Sodium bicarbonate is given to correct the acidosis caused by the toxicity and also acts as an antidote to stabilize cardiac conduction. Induced vomiting is not recommended due to the risk of aspiration. Norepinephrine will increase blood pressure and worsen the patient’s tachycardia. Diazepam will further depress respiration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has overdosed on clomipramine, which can lead to cardiac toxicity and respiratory depression. Widening of QRS complexes on ECG suggests sodium channel blockade. Treatment for tricyclic antidepressant overdose includes sodium bicarbonate, which can help correct the acidosis and enhance sodium influx into cells and reverse the sodium channel blockade. Induced vomiting is not recommended due to the risk of aspiration. Norepinephrine can worsen blood pressure and cardiac toxicity, and diazepam is a sedative, which can further depress respiratory and cardiovascular function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a tricyclic antidepressant overdose, leading to cardiac conduction abnormalities and respiratory depression. Sodium bicarbonate can help correct the cardiac conduction abnormalities by increasing the extracellular pH. Induced vomiting is not recommended due to the risk of aspiration. Norepinephrine can worsen the symptoms, and Diazepam is not helpful in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose, and the widening of QRS complexes in the ECG confirms it. Sodium bicarbonate is the first line of treatment for TCA overdose to prevent cardiac arrhythmias. Induced vomiting is not recommended in this case as the patient is already unresponsive, and it may further harm her. Norepinephrine is contraindicated as it may worsen the cardiac toxicity of TCAs. Diazepam is not indicated for TCA overdose.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient likely overdosed on clomipramine, and the widening of QRS complexes suggests sodium channel blockade. Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat QRS prolongation caused by tricyclic antidepressants. Induced vomiting is not appropriate for an unresponsive patient. Norepinephrine and diazepam would not be effective in treating the toxic effects of clomipramine.
